```{python}
#| echo: false
#| execute: true

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Set default plotting parameters
plt.rcParams.update({
    'font.size': 10,
    'lines.linewidth': 1,
    'lines.markersize': 5,
    'axes.labelsize': 10,
    'xtick.labelsize': 10,
    'ytick.labelsize': 10,
    'xtick.top': True,
    'xtick.direction': 'in',
    'ytick.right': True,
    'ytick.direction': 'in',
})

def get_size(w, h):
    return (w/2.54, h/2.54)
```



# Introduction

Since the beginning of the 2st century, the field of chemistry has been revolutionized by the development of new techniques and methods.


```{python}
#| echo: false
#| fig-cap: "Das ist wieder ein schönes Bild. Box Method Illustration"
#| label: fig-first-plot

x=np.linspace(0,2*np.pi,100)
y=np.sin(x)

plt.figure(figsize=get_size(7, 6))
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.xlabel("x [cm]")
plt.ylabel("y [cm]")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

As shown in @fig-first-plot, the sine function is a periodic function that repeats itself every $2\pi$. This is pretty neat since I only have to plot the range from 0 to $2\pi$ to see the entire function.

```{python}
#| echo: false

#| label: fig-second-plot
y=np.cos(x)
plt.figure(figsize=get_size(7, 6))
plt.plot(x,y)
plt.xlabel("x [cm]")
plt.ylabel("y [cm]")
plt.show()
```


As shown in  @fig-second-plot, this is a cosinus function.

$$
y=\cos(x)
$${#eq-black-scholes}
